coredata.dc:title: Large-scale computational models of liver metabolism: How far from the clinics?
coredata.dc:publisher:
John Wiley and Sons Inc.
P.O.Box 18667 Newark NJ 07191-8667

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2017 by the American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases.
abstract.ce:para: Understanding the dynamics of human liver metabolism is fundamental for effective diagnosis and treatment of liver diseases. This knowledge can be obtained with systems biology/medicine approaches that account for the complexity of hepatic responses and their systemic consequences in other organs. Computational modeling can reveal hidden principles of the system by classification of individual components, analyzing their interactions and simulating the effects that are difficult to investigate experimentally. Herein, we review the state-of-the-art computational models that describe liver dynamics from metabolic, gene regulatory, and signal transduction perspectives. We focus especially on large-scale liver models described either by genome scale metabolic networks or an object-oriented approach. We also discuss the benefits and limitations of each modeling approach and their value for clinical applications in diagnosis, therapy, and prevention of liver diseases as well as precision medicine in hepatology. (Hepatology 2017;66:1323-1334).

affiliation.affilname: Universitätsklinikum des Saarlandes Medizinische Fakultät der Universität des Saarlandes
University of Ljubljana Faculty of Medicine

xocs:funding.xocs:funding-agency: Javna Agencija za Raziskovalno Dejavnost RS

xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: Received November 2, 2016; accepted May 11, 2017. Supported by the resources of FP7 CASyM (Coordinating Action Systems Medicine Europe, grant no. 305033), the BMBF grant LiSyM (Liver Systems Medicine, grant no. 031L005), and by Slovenian Research Agency grants P1-0390, P2-0359, J1-6740, and the infrastructure grant ELIXIR.

item-info.copyright: Copyright 2017 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

citation-title.titletext: Large-scale computational models of liver metabolism: How far from the clinics?

affiliation.organization: Centre for Functional Genomics and Bio-Chips
Faculty of Computer and Information Science
Centre for Functional Genomics and Bio-Chips

abstract.ce:para: Understanding the dynamics of human liver metabolism is fundamental for effective diagnosis and treatment of liver diseases. This knowledge can be obtained with systems biology/medicine approaches that account for the complexity of hepatic responses and their systemic consequences in other organs. Computational modeling can reveal hidden principles of the system by classification of individual components, analyzing their interactions and simulating the effects that are difficult to investigate experimentally. Herein, we review the state-of-the-art computational models that describe liver dynamics from metabolic, gene regulatory, and signal transduction perspectives. We focus especially on large-scale liver models described either by genome scale metabolic networks or an object-oriented approach. We also discuss the benefits and limitations of each modeling approach and their value for clinical applications in diagnosis, therapy, and prevention of liver diseases as well as precision medicine in hepatology.
